body: To the Editor: Re ''Time to Deal With E-Waste'' (editorial, Dec. 9): In Cologne, Germany, on every block or so there are large recycling containers. Every few days, residents place their items to be recycled (paper, glass, plastic, e-material) in the appropriate containers. This way, the sorting is already done. These containers eliminate the
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Lessons in Recycling And Getting Rid of Mail

body: It was just a short time after the assassination on Thursday of Benazir Bhutto at a political rally in Pakistan that word of her death began spreading through the quiet blocks of Midwood in Brooklyn and Astoria and Jackson Heights in Queens, neighborhoods with some of the city's largest Pakistani populations. From house to house, corner to corner,
title: Shock in Pakistani Enclaves in New York

body: ''You just have to be careful,'' said Jeffrey Watler, wearing a winter coat over the collared shirt required by his employer, a messenger service. Knapsack on his back, he threaded his way through pedestrians, bike messengers and dogs on the way to his next pickup near Grand Central Terminal. For Mr. Watler, 25, who walks with an impaired gait and
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Treacherous Streets With Limited Mobility

body: Forgive? Perhaps not. Forget? Um, forget about it. But half a century after Walter O'Malley ripped the heart out of Brooklyn by moving the Dodgers to Los Angeles, quite a few Brooklynites seemed grudgingly willing to congratulate Mr. O'Malley on his posthumous election yesterday to the National Baseball Hall of Fame. ''Yeah, he deserves it,'' David
title: New Hall of Famer Stirs Both Sides in Brooklyn

body: MORE than a neighborhood, Flatbush often refers to a sprawling community in central Brooklyn comprising multiple smaller ones. ''It really seems like a catchall for anything,'' said Lenny Linsker, a real estate investor. ''If an area is not definitely a different part of Brooklyn, it's Flatbush.'' But many smaller neighborhoods traditionally under
title: LIVING IN | FLATBUSH, BROOKLYN; Note to City Dwellers: Steals Available Here

body: A 14-year-old boy who was fatally stabbed in a Brooklyn park on Friday had been trying to rob an acquaintance of the youth who stabbed him, the police said yesterday. Investigators said the stabbing occurred about 3:50 p.m. on Friday in Kolbert Park in Midwood. The 14-year-old boy, Marcell Dawes, died at 4:37 p.m. at New York Community Hospital.
title: 14-Year-Old Killed in Brooklyn Park

body: MASLOW--Robert, 66, of Brooklyn, NY died October 30, 2007. He is survived by his children, Susan, Peter, and Katy, and his sister Linda. Memorial service at Midwood Chapel, November 11, 2007, 12-2pm.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MASLOW, ROBERT

body: In an effort to transform the city's gifted and talented programs, which he has long derided as a hodgepodge of offerings that have favored children in certain neighborhoods and with well-connected parents, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced a plan yesterday to limit the programs to students who score in the top 5 percent on admissions
title: Schools Raise Bar for Classes For the Gifted

author: Gabriel Thompson is the author of ''There's No Jos√© Here: Following the Hidden Lives of Mexican Immigrants.'' His most recent book is ''Calling All Radicals.''
body: HUDOYKUL HAFIZOV, a soft-spoken, slightly built immigrant from Uzbekistan, works as inventory manager at Silver Rod Pharmacy in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and he has a favorite joke: ''A person who knows three languages is trilingual. ''Someone who knows two languages is bilingual. ''But do you know what they call a person who speaks only one
title: The United Nations of Brooklyn

body: The advertisements are typical of those you find around the holidays, graduation time or ethnic heritage days: a City Council member expresses best wishes, and uses taxpayer dollars to do it. From 2002 to 2006, council members spent a total of nearly $200,000 a year on advertisements, but most were little more than self-promotional and many may
title: Advertising By Members Of Council Draws Fire

body: ZALMAN--Violette , (nee Bardavid) died peacefully at home on October 10, 2007 at age 96. Treasured by her sons, Benjamin (Denise), Marvin (Greta). She will be missed by her loving grandchildren Debbie, Amy, David and Seth and great-grandchildren, Benjamin and Hazel Rose. Services Friday, October 12th at 11:00am at Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ZALMAN, VIOLETTE

body: A picture last Sunday with an article about a proposed historic-district designation for the adjacent Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fiske Terrace and Midwood Park was published in error. The photograph showed West Midwood, an area next to Fiske Terrace and Midwood Park.
title: Correction: Aging Beauties, Factory-Made

body: Dr. Emily Margaret Stein, an endocrinologist in New York, and Jonathan Philip Berenbom, a reinsurance executive, are to be married this evening. Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman is to officiate at the Yale Club of New York City. Dr. Stein, 32, will keep her name. She is an instructor of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons,
title: Emily Stein, Jonathan Berenbom

body: Manhattan EAST VILLAGE $635,000 141 East Third Street (First Avenue) (Ageloff Towers) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; manned elevator; windowed eat-in kitchen, beamed ceilings, new windows, south and west exposures, original detail; common roof deck in building; maintenance $656, 50% tax deductible; listed at $635,000, 18
title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: Fiske Terrace and Midwood Park look and feel much as they did a century ago, when the conjoined neighborhoods were built on razed farmland in central Brooklyn. Their grand wood frame houses in the Queen Anne and Colonial Revival styles, with broad front porches, peaked roofs and lush gardens, evoke gracious country living within the city. It is not
title: FISKE TERRACE/MIDWOOD PARK; Aging Beauties, Factory-Made

body: THE national median home price right now is $224,500. But finding anything even close to that in New York -- where the average sale price for a Manhattan apartment hovers just above $1.3 million -- would be like snagging a seat on a downtown No. 6 train at the height of rush hour. Or would it? In the current market, staying in Manhattan for
title: Even in New York, Affordable Apartments

body: NOT everyone who works in the Steve's C-Town supermarket, on Ninth Street near Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, is a teenager. It can, however, seem that way to a customer, waiting in the long express line that curves toward the seltzer display and the frozen foods while the stock boys flirt with the cash register girls, the delivery guys lounge out
title: PIN MONEY; Angst Amid the Artichokes

body: THE word ''beach'' in the name of a New York neighborhood is no proof of the presence of sand. Bath Beach, for instance, doesn't have any. Yet Manhattan Beach, on a peninsula in Brooklyn's southeastern corner, has not just one beach, but two. To start with, there is the 400-foot-wide crescent at Kingsborough Community College, whose 70-acre campus
title: LIVING IN | MANHATTAN BEACH, BROOKLYN; A Little Land With a Lot of Sand

body: There is an almost eerie quiet as New York City approaches the September 18 primary elections. No federal, statewide, citywide, City Council, or state legislative posts are at issue, making this the least active primary season in recent memory. This has produced a quirky result: The primary's marquee events are three judicial contests in Brooklyn.
title: THE CITY; A Quiet (and Disquieting) Primary

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: The last straw for Simcha Felder came months ago. Actually, it was more like the last scrap of paper. His mother had been given a $100 sanitation summons for some advertisement fliers that lay messily on the sidewalk in front of her house in Borough Park, Brooklyn. You've all seen those kinds of fliers and their pesky first cousins: restaurant
title: NYC; Of Fliers, Fines And the Limits Of Patience

body: CLEO BABBITT has just tied her doppelg√§nger, Gwen Munson, to the railroad tracks, the better to seduce Gwen's devoted husband, Will. Aaron Snyder has decided to forgive his girlfriend, Alison, for her stint as a porn star and to believe that she will finally be able to quit using crystal meth. In other words, it's business as usual in Midwood,
title: Midwood; Living Alongside Love in the Afternoon

body: BADER--Martin, 72, on July 23rd in Seattle, WA. Beloved husband of Roberta Lokin Bader (Bobby). Devoted father and grandfather, brotherin-law and friend. Services Thursday July 26th, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, 1pm.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BADER, MARTIN

body: To the Editor: All New Yorkers who are old enough have memories of that night 30 years ago. I was working part time in a liquor store on 57th Street, and I remember watching the entire West Side go dark. I also recall the shame that I felt as I watched the televised images of all those housewives looting their neighborhood stores of anything they
title: That Dark Night 30 Years Ago

body: A popular Brooklyn pizzeria reopened on Saturday nearly three weeks after it was cited by the city health department for unsanitary conditions. Di Fara Pizza, at East 15th Street and Avenue J in Midwood, was closed after it failed an inspection on June 4, when inspectors found flies, a mouse infestation and bare-hand contact with food. That was the
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Pizzeria Reopens

body: When people call Felice Frankel an artist, she winces. In the first place, the photographs she makes don't sell. She knows this, she says, because after she received a Guggenheim grant in 1995, she started taking her work to galleries. ''Nobody wanted to bother looking,'' she said. In the second place, her images are not full of emotion or ideology
title: She Calls It 'Phenomena.' Everyone Else Calls It Art.

body: It was about lunchtime yesterday when Eugene Kaplun stood in front of a pizzeria in Brooklyn, not believing what he was seeing. He read the yellow sign. He read the brown sign. Neither was a menu. The yellow sign, a notice of closing, had been posted by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The brown sign was a more personal note from
title: A Beloved Brooklyn Pizzeria Is Closed, Again, by the Health Dept.

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: IF they could have predicted the future, Julie and Neil Weintraub would have bought a one-bedroom co-op, not a two-bedroom, for their first home. As their family grew, they began hunting for a larger one. But they let several opportunities pass, reluctant to commit to a new place until they sold their old one. That took more than a year. ''On some
title: THE HUNT; A Crystal Ball Would Have Been Nice

body: APPROPRIATELY enough, percussion from construction hammers provides the audio backdrop at the Midtown office of Avi Schick, the sumo-size former deputy in Eliot Spitzer's hyperactive attorney general's office. Now, at the request of Governor Spitzer, he wears a double hard hat as president of the Empire State Development Corporation and, starting
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Juggling a Pair of Policy Jobs, to the Music of Hammers

body: It is early afternoon, 20 minutes into G band -- or sixth period -- at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn. But today, Shawn Martinez, a third-year student, and one of the stars of its national championship chess team, is nowhere near school. Instead, while his classmates memorize the periodic table of the elements, perform Shakespeare or
title: At 16, a Star at the Chessboard, But Adrift in School and Life

Adored grandfather to Danielle Gross and greatgrandfather to Jacob Tyler Gross. Services 11:30 today at Midwood Memorial Chapel 1625 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn (corner
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COHEN, OSCAR J

body: Woodland Contemporary $1,895,000 NASSAU COUNTY: 41 Valley Road, Old Westbury A five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house on two acres surrounded by hiking trails owned by the State University of New York at Old Westbury. Centered in the living room is a stone wall housing a chimney with dual-sided fireplace. Michael Piccolo, Daniel Gale Sotheby's
title: ON THE MARKET

body: KAMEN--Fay, peacefully on March 8, 2007, at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Ephraim. Loving mother of Barbara and Michael and mother-in-law of Sandy and Geoffrey. Devoted and cherished grandmother of Jeremy, Mathew, Jessica, Heather, Elise and Efrem. Blessed with 10 great-grandchildren. She was deeply involved with the Yeshiva of Flatbush
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KAMEN, FAY

body: Two men were found dead yesterday evening in a garage in Brooklyn that was damaged by a fire, officials said. The bodies of the men, who had not been identified as of late last night, were discovered after firefighters put out a fire in a one-story garage at 1695 East 21st Street near Kings Highway in Midwood, a neighborhood of well-kept two-story
title: 2 Men Are Found Dead in Brooklyn Garage Where Fire Broke Out

body: The sites were not glamorous -- a raceway in Yonkers, a union hall in Hauppauge on Long Island, the Emerald Queen Casino in Tacoma, Wash. -- and the pay was not great, either. He earned anywhere from $50 to $12,000 per fight, and sometimes a night at a discount motel and a day's worth of meal vouchers. Still, Kemal Kolenovic loved the fighting life
title: Boxer, 28, Killed in Hit and Run Savored Hard-Knock Life
